Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 4: Handling and Storage of Hazardous Materials and the Appropriate Disposal of Bio-contaminants 

Why are young children at such a risk?

Letâ€™s look at some factors that result in children being at a higher risk for exposure to hazardous chemicals.

Exploring by Taste

Infants are still using taste to explore their worlds by placing items in their mouth or licking them. Toddlers and preschoolers touch many surfaces and average placing their fingers in their mouths 9 to 10 times an hour.

More Ground Exposure

Whether crawling or playing, infants and young children spend hours close to the ground where there is more exposure to toxins in dust, soil, and floors and carpets.

Hygiene Habits

Young children have not developed good hygiene habits yet, so they are frequently touching surfaces and body parts and the inside of their mouths. 

Higher Metabolism

Per unit of body weight, children consume more food and water than adults and have higher metabolisms. Children breathe more rapidly and thus take in more air. Their immature organs are especially sensitive, and their external surfaces absorb more toxic material. Their rapid growth increases the long-term accumulation of chemicals. In the United States, the increased vulnerability of children regarding toxic exposure is 10 times more for infants.

It is important to remember that lack of supervision is a primary reason children get into toxic materials. It only takes a second of not watching an infant or child for it to turn into a life or death situation.
